Earning a passive income while helping to secure a network sounds as comfortable as it is noble. The reality, however, is that most masternode coins are scams, according to a recent news.bitcoin.com post.

Many nodes, but little use

Every trader has a strategy to take advantage of the good times and the scarcity. Some buy ICOs and hope the market will recover; and some set up masternodes.

Dash is the altcoin credited with starting the mainnode craze. When the coin was trading for less than a dollar, the Proof of Work coin featured a master system that required staking 1,000 Dash.

Top 10 masternodes by market capitalization. Check how thin the volume is for many of them.

The plan proved hugely successful, both as a means of governing the network, and as a source of income for individuals running a node, who were being handsomely compensated when the crypto market boomed in 2017.

At its peak, it would have cost $1.5 million to buy enough DASHs to set up a masternode. The success of the plan, which made early adopters of the Dash master system very wealthy, was soon copied by countless coins.

Dash has at least a modicum of real-world utility, but most of the imitators that have sprung up since then have no other goal than to enrich their early adopters and executors.

Masternode coins are the new lending platforms

The crypto winter of 2018 has been especially nasty for master coins. Dash has been on a slide since mid-December, when it peaked at $1,580 per coin, and stands today at $320.

Lesser known masternode coins have fared even worse. Yearto.Date maintains a list of the best and worst masternode coins of 2018, and it’s not pretty, even the third best performing coin of the year is in the red.

Although masternode coins are not a scam in the Bitconnect sense like lending platforms, they are a scheme that looks profitable in a bull market when everything is pumping. Sites like Cryptopia and Trade Satoshi are graveyards where abandoned master coins go to die.

Masternodes as a service

Setting up a masternode is relatively easy, all you need is a VPS and the ability to change a few lines of Linux code, but for those who lack the know-how, services like Digital Price will take care of setup and hosting.

Even without getting your hands dirty, running a masternode is still a risky business given the potential for your staked coins to return 90% of their value in a matter of months.

However, volatility works both ways, and it is also possible to make huge profits from the masternode coins being pumped, usually because they are being bought in bulk by other traders who are also looking for stake coins. This type of system is unsustainable, of course, and when a bunch of node operators decide to dump their leftover coins, the market crashes.

Despite these inherent weaknesses, the concept of masternodes remains strong: it’s just that for the system to work, the network must be worth protecting in the first place, and for that to happen, the currency must be used for more than just staking. – such as remittances, P2P payments or e-commerce. As a result, it makes more sense for developers to focus on generating demand for a blockchain first, rather than launching masternodes and hoping the utility will follow.

Newer projects like Origin Protocol, Dadi, Essentia, REMME, and Zencash will add masternodes in the future. The difference, with these networks, is that the nodes will be a feature rather than the defining one. The next generation of masternode coins could actually be worth something. The current generation are mostly scamcoins.
